The Art Gallery

Collection of artworks that represents the story in some way.
×

“A Fun Playdate”

by Nicole Josef


This piece features an obelisk, Bruce’s tombstone, among a few common children’s toys. This represents how Alison spent her childhood in the Fun Home, playing with her brothers as her father embalmed dead bodies. Ultimately, the piece also shows how Alison becomes desensitized to death.

×

“Do Not Touch”

by Nicole Josef


In this piece, we see a bouquet of colorful flowers outside a window. Beside this bouquet is a sign that says “Do not touch.” The flowers represent Bruce’s obsession with beautifying the house. The Do Not Touch sign signifies how this obsession caused a rift between Bruce and his children, just as Alison had shared.

×

“Out of Mind”

by Oyi Tapia


The photo shows a creature and its reflection having a lightbulb as its head. This symbolizes the presence of Bruce in Alison’s life. Having the creature be almost indistinguishable from its reflection in which it floats above it shows this out-of-touch feeling that Alison gets when she looks at her father. While this glowing and none proportional head show that Bruce is being pulled away by the overwhelming thoughts in his head.
